setup.question: What is the real reason the characters are stationed on the moon?
answers: It’s just a stopover on the way to Venus

Text.text: A seems less likely to be a clandestine reason.
The only time Venus is mentioned is in the beginning of the story, where someone says
and after he explains his hesitance
an old man says
; this, however, is all happening on Earth as the old man is revealed to be

, who is one of the characters we later see on the moon.

The characters on the moon are conducting some sort of research, as it's mentioned that

, making them the second research group.

When the characters are discussing what they're gonna do when they get back to Earth, one of them says

.

It seems they're running an assortment of experiments, as two of them
. For another, Donley,

I'm confused by: "this, however, is all happening on Earth as the old man is revealed to be Chapman, who is one of the characters we later see on the moon." Why wouldn't this conversation be happening on Earth? And how does Chapman being on the moon imply that they are conversing on Earth?

Another thing I'm confused about: what is the *ostensible* reason the characters are stationed on the moon? The question, by asking for the "real reason", implies the existence of some surface reason which is not the real one. What is that reason? And how does them doing research fit into that ostensible reason?
The first scene is present day, and the story is told as a flashback of the older man (Chapman)'s time on the moon:
We know this because at the end of the story Chapman does come back to earth and he isn't "an old man" then. Also, here,
while on the moon the crew lived
There is no reason given other than research experiments, the characters mention being paid by
, who offer Chapman more money to stay on the moon but he declines:

- Fill in the missing quotes at the beginning of the story, between "to Venus" (296) and "The older man smiled" (446).
- What's the situation of the "they'd be relieved by the members of the Third research group" quote? Where would the Third research group be coming to, where would they go after this, and what actually ended up happening?
- What happened between the descriptions of research ('some strata he wished to investigate, 2425) and the last quote you gave (6498-)?
- Why was Chapman not interested in staying?

(out of quotes)

Right now the crew is on the moon and the third research group (TRG) is coming to relieve them. They will swap places and the crew will go back to earth while the TRG stays on the moon.

After 2425 and 6498 the crew conducts some more of their experiments, there's a bit more exposition, and then the TRG's ship lands on the moon.

Chapman's not interested in staying because of the terrible conditions on the moon, see "cramped, smelly little hut"

Ok, some followup questions:
- "It's nice to have the new air units now. There was a time when we had to be very careful about things like smoking." — What is this about? Why did they have to be careful about smoking? You said they're on Earth. Can you provide evidence of that?
- Please give evidence between 296–446 that backs up your claim that Chapman is the one who stares at the radio key.
- What is the point of this story? From what you've described, it sounds very mundane.
- What is the context for the offer you quoted at the end, where Chapman is asked to stay on the moon? Why would they ask him this if TRG is coming to replace him?

smoking refers to smoking on the bases on other planets, the tech has been updated for the venus trip so now they can smoke

i have, go to the quotes page

chapman is asked to stay because:

they want him to help the transition of the next research group.

the point of this story is to provide a counter-narrative to how space has been glorified in most sci-fi stories and chapman's reluctance to stay is an example of that.

1. You said smoking refers to smoking on the bases of other planets, but earlier you said this conversation was taking place on Earth. Where is the conversation taking place? Provide evidence for your claim. You're not answering my question.
2. No, you have not provided any quotes between 296–446. Please fill in between 296–446 as much as you can.
3. Can you provide evidence of this counter-narrative being important to the story? Is there any way in which the assumption of the glorification of space is reflected in the story's text? This seems unintuitive to me, because even at the very beginning one of the characters is not keen on going to space.

yes, the whole point is that going to space is revealed to be something the characters are hesitant to do or at least find out that it isn't all they've dreamed of because of all the hassles and tough living conditions of space, all the cramped stations, tinned food, etc. (can provide quotes for those).

You still haven't answered my question about the air, and about where the conversation is. And the quote you provided did not help me understand whether Chapman is the older man in that conversation. Please address this point.

what question about the air? I've proven that the conversation isn't taking place on the moon nor have they gotten to venus yet, (the young man is asked to be on the "first" expedition to venus), which leaves earth as the only place they could be.

the passage i quoted grammatically refers to chapman as the older man, as the two actions being done in continuation are described as being done by the older man -> chapman, or in other words, the same person.

No, you have not proven those things.
— Question about the air: 3 speeches up, I asked "what is this about?" and you gave me a very cursory answer which also contradicts your claim that the convo is on Earth (since you said it refers to smoking on other planets).
— The passage does NOT grammatically refer to Chapman as the older man. Grammatically it is ambiguous, and pragmatically the use there reads to me exactly the opposite — ie that Chapman is someone else — otherwise a pronoun like "he" would have been appropriate. Consistent use of 'very young man' and the 'older man' without names implies their names are revealed later or neither of them is Chapman.

Fill in 234–277 and 415–446, and use the rest of your quotes to expand after 472.

Ah, so it is Chapman... I think I get it. The conversation at the beginning happens long after the main story, but it's on the moon. The conditions are different because the moon has been properly colonized — hence the comment about the air. And the conceit is that at the very end, he doesn't want to stay any longer, but he ends up being a lifer. The foreshadowing in "but sometimes it's sooner than you think" helped clarify this. By this narrative you have certainly lied, but ironically, I still have no idea why the moon would just be a stopover on the way to Venus. The only clue is "And the goal is worth it."

— What's the "goal"?
— Fill in 472-518, max out quote budget with relevant info, & give your strongest refutation of my narrative.

The "goal" is not mentioned in that paragraph nor in the ones that follow. The only reference to an aim of their work would be the various experiments (see my prev quotes) that the astronauts perform. The relief ship mentions this too:
. Even when the relief captain is trying to convince Chapman to stay he adds that
You didn't refute my story at all but I want to be really sure. Please fill in 518-565 and use any available space you have left to refute my point about the first meeting happening on the moon.
No refutation, I probably just misread the beginning, but I'm correct about Chapman being the older man.

Okay. Refutation matters because if he's still on the moon, why would you lie about him going back to Earth? Presumably because it's a stopover on the way to Venus? One final point which you haven't addressed which I want to give one more chance: what is the "goal" Chapman is referring to when he says "the goal is worth it"? And why are the people who go on the voyage "reluctant heroes"? What makes them heroes? If you don't have some explanation of this dialogue or the story's title, I'll be forced to believe you're definitely dishonest.

There is no place in the story that the "goal" is explicitly referred to. I've provided evidence that what the people were doing on the Moon were scientific experiments as well as the end of the story where a relief crew comes /to the moon/ to take their place. Reluctant heroes refers to the crewmembers (like Chapman) ending up miserable on the moon because of the bad living conditions and wanting to come back to earth. I haven't lied about earth, Chapman does want to go back to earth which is where the rest of the crew want to go after their shift as well:

- Inability to answer the question at hand
- Lie exposed earlier in the debate
- Disingenuously quoting Chapman's desire to go back home from early in the story when we've already established he's still on the moon many years later
- Lack of ability to explain the point of the story in any way that is not very mundane

It's really hard for me to see this as a case of an honest debater, even though it's also hard for me to see what the explanation for answer A is. I probably dragged this too long.

answers.reason for outcome: I made a mistake and accidentally lied

answers.other: If I'm right that this is Jackson, he accidentally made a comment in my presence that leaked that he was the honest debater in a debate where the judge was slowly losing confidence in him and he didn't know what to do. I was worried that this was me, but I blocked the possibility out of my head and pretended I didn't know that for the purpose of judging this. (update: it was not Jackson, lol. so I guess I'm good on that front... BUT, if I HAD assumed it was Jackson and then concluded the answer was actually B, would we say I "knew" the answer was B? After all, wouldn't it then be a true justified belief???? Hmmmm???? Yes?????)
answers.reason for outcome: I identified a critical untruth by the debater (which the debater conceded to!) which heavily beared on the story. Lots of odd things about the language of the question ("real" reason) and story ("the goal is worth it") went unexplained, and no reasonable theme for the story was presented. The debater continued to provide non-useful answers to my questions and several turns passed with the debater going woefully short of their evidence quota. All of these factors together led me to guess that the debater was almost certainly dishonest, even though I couldn't identify a plausible explanation for answer A.
answers.judge strategies: I asked for lots of specific quotes to be expanded, pressed on high-level issues about the point of the story, and penalized the debater for failing to deliver.
